text: it was the question on everyone's mind
when President Obama's budget landed on
Thursday what was the impact going to be
on taxes and who was going to bear the
disproportionate impact it turns out
that those who are most affluent are
going to bear the biggest brunt of this
so let's start there if you make two
hundred thousand dollars in their single
or if you earn $250,000 or more and you
filed your taxes jointly with your
spouse you're likely to bear the biggest
brunt here it's going to happen in a
number of ways first of all the tax
brackets are going to change lightly
change slightly so that you're paying a
higher tax rate as far as capital gains
go the long-term rate is going to
increase from fifteen to twenty percent
with this proposal if you work for a
private equity firm your many of your
earnings now are going to be at the more
expensive regular ordinary income rate
and no longer at the capital gains rate
deductions get affected too you're going
to get a little bit less credit on the
deduction front for mortgages and for
charitable deductions and other itemized
deductions as well so there are a number
of ways that you're potentially impacted
if you're up a more moderate income say
between seventy-five thousand and two
hundred thousand dollars in household
income there are a couple of advantages
here there's an expanded credit for
college students up to four thousand
dollars in tuition spending that comes
back to you in the form of a twenty five
hundred dollar credit which is partially
refundable so that's an improvement on
what existed before there's also what's
called the making work pay credit that's
either four hundred dollars if you're
single or eight hundred dollars if
you're married and finally filing
jointly up to a certain income cap now
if you're lower-income probably the best
news here comes in something that's
being referred to alternatively as the
automatic IRA or the universal savings
account what's going to happen here if
the proposal goes through is that
employers who do not currently offer a
retirement plan like a 401k if they have
more than 10 employees they're gonna
have to start offering one now and the
way that it will work is through payroll
deduction where you'll be automatically
signed up to have a little bit of your
salary siphoned off into an IRA that
will probably go into something like a
target date where
and fund so if you don't want to
participate you'll have to sort of take
some affirmative action and opt out
they'll also be a tax credit here that
goes into the account effectively it's a
match on your savings of up to fifty
percent for a thousand dollars in
savings per year so it's sort of like
working for an employer that has an
employee match so that's probably the
best news for folks in the lower income
range now again we have to remember that
these are just proposals there's going
to be a fair amount of haggling and
Congress over this but right now it
appears as if the affluent are going to
pay more whether it's more than their
fair share of course is a question for
the ages i'm ron lieber for the new york
times
